thread.title: Butch Jones: "Aaron Medley is our kicker"
thread.title_full: Butch Jones: "Aaron Medley is our kicker"

title: Butch Jones: "Aaron Medley is our kicker"
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Butch Jones: "Aaron Medley is our kicker" Tennessee Volunteers football coach Butch Jones said Monday he was proud of the way his team played despite a 19-14 loss to Alabama over the weekend. Post to Facebook Butch Jones: "Aaron Medley is our kicker" Tennessee Volunteers football coach Butch Jones said Monday he was proud of the way his team played despite a 19-14 loss to Alabama over the weekend.  //on.wbir.com/1S6tKVA   Join the Conversation To   Butch Jones: "Aaron Medley is our kicker" WBIR Staff, WBIR 12:56 p.m. EDT October 26, 2015 Tennessee looks to bounce back against Kentucky Vols sophomore kicker Aaron Medley missed three field goals in Saturday's 19-14 loss to Alabama. Medley missed a 43-yard attempt and two 51-yarders against the Crimson Tide. (Photo: Kevin C. Cox, Getty Images) 
(WBIR – KNOXVLLE) Tennessee Volunteers football coach Butch Jones said Monday Aaron Medley would remain Tennessee's starting kicker despite making 52.9 percent of his field goals this season. 
Medley is 9-of-17 on the season. 
“I think that’s when you find out about everyone through shared adversity,” Jones said. “When you’re persevering you find out who’s really in it with you, and you found who’s not in it with you.” 
Medley, a sophomore, missed three long field goals in Tennessee’s 19-14 loss to Alabama . 
Jones said he was proud the way his team played despite the loss to the Crimson Tide. 
“I thought they played with great competitive grit,” Jones said. Vols held Tide to season-low output 
Jones said he anticipates that sophomore offensive lineman Jashon Roberts, redshirt sophomore offensive lineman Brett Kendrick and freshman wide receiver Preston Williams to be available for Saturday's game against Kentucky. Jones said he would know more about each player's condition later in the week. 
Jones complimented Kentucky quarterback Patrick Towles, and said that the junior is “a winner.” 
“I think he’s one of the best quarterbacks in our conference,” Jones said. 
Towles has 4,681 passing yards in his career, which is sixth in Kentucky history. 
Jones tried recruiting Towles when he was coaching at Cincinnati. 
The Wildcats are coming off of a 42-16 road loss to Mississippi State. It was Kentucky’s second loss in a row. 
Kentucky has a 4-3 record (2-3 SEC) coming into Saturday’s game against Tennessee. 
Tennessee will play on the road at Kentucky's Commonwealth Stadium on Saturday. The game will telecast at 7:30 p.m. Eastern Time on the SEC Network. Read or Share this story: http://on.wbir.com/1S6tKVA TOP VIDEOS
